verdict: Extremely high CPA ($316) with only 4 conversions — insufficient data for optimization; fundamental rethink needed

checks.name: Conversion actions defined
checks.finding: Only 4 conversions in 30 days — extremely low volume. Conversion tracking may be functional but needs verification

checks.name: Micro vs macro separation
checks.finding: With only 4 conversions, any micro-as-Primary issue would be catastrophic for bidding signals

checks.name: Conversion value assignment
checks.finding: No conversion value reported — DNA diet programs likely have specific price points that should be tracked

checks.name: Wasted spend on irrelevant terms
checks.finding: 2.8% conversion rate with $316 CPA. 137 of 141 clicks did not convert — search term quality needs urgent review

checks.name: Search term audit recency
checks.finding: BOFU campaign implies bottom-funnel targeting but $316 CPA and 2.8% CVR suggest targeting is too broad or wrong intent

checks.name: Negative keyword lists exist
checks.finding: Not verified — DNA/diet queries attract heavy informational traffic that must be excluded

checks.name: Campaign naming convention
checks.finding: CTM prefix with funnel stage (BOFU) — good naming convention

checks.name: Campaign count per objective
checks.finding: Single campaign — limits testing ability but appropriate for low budget

checks.name: Brand vs Non-Brand separation
checks.finding: No brand campaign. BOFU may be capturing some brand traffic at non-brand CPCs

checks.name: PMax present for eligible accounts
checks.finding: No PMax — but with only 4 conversions/month, PMax wouldn't have enough data anyway

checks.name: Search CTR performance
checks.finding: 4.4% CTR is mediocre for a niche health product — ads may not be compelling enough or keywords too broad

checks.name: Keyword intent alignment
checks.finding: DNA diet is a niche market. 'Bottom of funnel' implies purchase-ready keywords but 2.8% CVR says otherwise

checks.name: Search volume viability
checks.finding: 3,202 impressions in 30 days — very low volume. May be a market size issue, not just targeting

checks.name: CTR vs industry benchmark
checks.finding: 4.4% CTR is below health/wellness benchmark of ~6%. Ad messaging may not resonate

checks.name: Landing page effectiveness
checks.finding: 2.8% conversion rate on BOFU traffic is poor — landing page likely needs improvement: clearer value proposition, social proof, pricing

checks.name: Smart bidding strategy active
checks.finding: With only 4 conversions/month, smart bidding cannot optimize effectively. Manual CPC or Max Clicks may be more appropriate for data gathering

checks.name: Data volume for optimization
checks.finding: 4 conversions/month is far below the 15-30 needed for smart bidding to function. Bidding strategy needs rethinking

quickWins.action: Review search terms immediately — with $316 CPA, likely significant irrelevant traffic from DNA/diet informational queries
Add extensive negative keywords: free, what is, how does, reviews, reddit, DIY, test, ancestry, genetics (informational)
Verify conversion tracking — confirm purchases/sign-ups are being tracked, not just page views
Review landing page — 2.8% CVR on BOFU traffic needs immediate improvement (pricing clarity, testimonials, CTA)
Add conversion values to enable ROI-based decisions

items: Audit search terms — identify and exclude all informational DNA/diet queries
Verify conversion tracking is properly installed and firing
Improve landing page: clear pricing, testimonials, simple sign-up flow
Consider pausing while landing page is improved if CPA remains above $200
Test different keyword angles: DNA diet plan, personalized nutrition, genetic diet
Test ad copy variations emphasizing unique DNA-based approach
Switch to Max Clicks to gather more data before using conversion-based bidding
Launch a brand campaign if there's any brand search volume
If CPA drops below $150, gradually increase budget
Test YouTube/Display for awareness if search volume is limited
Build email nurture sequence for clicks that don't immediately convert
Consider if Google Ads is the right channel — evaluate Meta Ads for interest-based targeting
